narrators.full_name: Husayn ibn al-Sa'ib ibn Abi Lubaba

potential_issues.issue: Biographical entry without complete hadith text

IISGrade: Disconnections But All Narrators Are Ok

english_translation: Narrated by Abu Lubaba ibn al-Mundhir: When Allah forgave Abu Lubaba after his tawbah (repentance), he came to the Prophet ﷺ saying: 'I will indeed abandon the dwelling of my people wherein I committed the sin, and I will sever myself from my wealth as sadaqah for Allah and His Messenger.' The Prophet ﷺ said to him: 'One-third of it suffices for you.'

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn Abi Hafsa
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abi Hafsa (Abd al-Aziz or similar)

narrators.name: Husayn ibn al-Sa'ib
narrators.full_name: Husayn ibn al-Sa'ib ibn Abi Lubaba al-Ansari

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Muhammad ibn Abi Hafsa is graded as weak (Da'if) by Abu Hatim and others, which compromises the entire chain
Muhammad ibn Abi Hafsa is known for practicing tadlis, and uses عَنْ with al-Zuhri without explicit direct transmission term
Al-Zuhri is known as a mudallis (type 2) though generally reliable, but his use of عَنْ still presents some ambiguity

potential_issues.issue: Weak narrator at the beginning of chain
potential_issues.impact: Muhammad ibn Abi Hafsa is classified as weak by major hadith scholars including Abu Hatim. His presence at the beginning of the transmission chain significantly weakens the hadith's reliability regardless of other narrators' strength

potential_issues.issue: Tadlis by Muhammad ibn Abi Hafsa
potential_issues.impact: Muhammad ibn Abi Hafsa is known for practicing tadlis (concealment of the line of transmission). When using عَنْ without explicit direct hearing (سمعت or حدثنا), this creates uncertainty about the actual nature of transmission

potential_issues.issue: Use of عَنْ from al-Zuhri despite his known tadlis tendency
potential_issues.impact: Though al-Zuhri is generally considered reliable and his tadlis is type 2 (not affecting acceptance), the use of عَنْ combined with the already weak narrator above creates compounded ambiguity

The text mentions variant chains through Sulayman ibn Abd al-Rahman, Abdullah from al-Layth, and Ibn Ishaq, indicating multiple transmission paths for this story, which may suggest different versions or traditions

IISGrade: Problematic
Topics: Incident of Abu Lubaba's repentance and reconciliation with the Prophet ﷺ
Repentance after witnessing disclosure of hypocrites' location
Prophet's ﷺ guidance on proper recompense for atonement

english_translation: Commentary by Abu Abdullah: I believe he is the first mentioned. Good appearance. Ahmad ibn Thabit narrated to us, narrated to us Bishr ibn al-Hasan Abu Malik, brother of Husayn.

chainIssues: Abu Abdullah is unidentified and his reliability is completely unknown
Ahmad ibn Thabit's identity is unclear and his grade is unknown
Bishr ibn al-Hasan's identity and reliability are not clearly established

potential_issues.issue: Biographical commentary rather than hadith transmission
potential_issues.impact: This entry consists of commentary and evaluation by an unknown scholar (Abu Abdullah) rather than transmission of an actual hadith with established chain
The narrators mentioned (Ahmad ibn Thabit and Bishr ibn al-Hasan) have unknown or unclear status in hadith sciences, making the reliability of any transmission impossible to assess
Without clear identification of the speakers and the subject being discussed, the actual content and purpose of this entry cannot be properly evaluated

IISGrade: Problematic

english_translation: Narrated by Husayn ibn al-Rammas al-Abdi: I heard Abd al-Rahman ibn Masud who heard from Salman that the Prophet ﷺ commanded us: 'Do not trouble the guest with that which we do not have available, but present what is available to us.'

narrators.name: Abd al-Rahman ibn Masud
narrators.full_name: Abd al-Rahman ibn Masud ibn Umayyah

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Husayn ibn al-Rammas is majhul al-hal with no clear documentation of reliability
Abd al-Rahman ibn Masud is likewise majhul al-hal with no established reliability grade
Both early narrators in the chain lack proper documentation of their reliability status

potential_issues.issue: Multiple narrators with unknown reliability status
potential_issues.impact: Both Husayn ibn al-Rammas and Abd al-Rahman ibn Masud are classified as majhul al-hal. This means while multiple narrators may have reported from them, their reliability is not documented, making the chain weak

potential_issues.issue: Connection between lesser-known narrators and the companion
potential_issues.impact: The chain depends on Abd al-Rahman ibn Masud having actually heard from Salman, which requires verification. Being contemporaries does not guarantee direct transmission

potential_issues.issue: Early narrators lack documentation in major hadith sources
potential_issues.impact: The absence of these narrators from the most reliable hadith collections and biographical dictionaries suggests they were not major transmitters, affecting the chain's strength

IISGrade: Problematic
Topics: Prohibition of burdensome expectations from hosts
Presentation of available provisions without excess

english_translation: From Imran ibn Muslim, from Khaythama: I was with Ibn Abbas regarding vows. Muhammad ibn Aqabah said: Ruh ibn Ataa narrated to us, he said: Husayn ibn Imran narrated to us. Imran al-Qattan reported from Husayn, from al-Shibani. Abu Dumra said: Husayn ibn Imran narrated to us, from al-Zuhri, strange narrations (munakir).

narrators.name: Ibn Abbas
narrators.full_name: Abdullah ibn Abbas ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Chain through Imran ibn Muslim and Khaythama has weak links with unknown reliability
Both early narrators are majhul al-hal
The hadith stops at Ibn Abbas (mawquf), making it a companion saying rather than prophetic tradition
Ruh ibn Ataa is known as a weak narrator
Husayn ibn Imran is explicitly noted to have munkar (rejected) narrations from al-Zuhri
Multiple chains through this narrator are marked as unreliable
Abu Dumra's evaluation explicitly states these are 'manakirur' (strange/rejected narrations)

potential_issues.impact: Ruh ibn Ataa and especially Husayn ibn Imran al-Jahni are both classified as weak narrators, with the latter having explicit documentation of munkar (rejected) narrations
Abu Dumra explicitly states that Husayn ibn Imran's narrations from al-Zuhri are 'manakirur' (rejected/strange narrations), indicating a well-known problem with this narrator's reliability
The text explicitly notes 'wala yutabi' fi hadithih' (there is no corroboration in his hadith), indicating this narrator is isolated in his narrations without support from other reliable chains
The various chains through different narrators (Imran al-Qattan, Abu Dumra) all have problems, suggesting systemic weakness in the transmission of this material

IISGrade: Problematic
Topics: Scholarly evaluation of weak narrator Husayn ibn Imran al-Jahni

english_translation: From Karib and Ikrimah. Ali said: I abandoned his hadith. Sharik said: From Husayn, from Ikrimah, from Ibn Abbas, the Prophet ﷺ said about Umm Ibrahim: 'Free her,' but this did not become authentic. Amr said, from Ataa, from Ibn Abbas: Mother slaves are only like your goat or your camel. Abu Abdullah said: This is what is well-known from the fatwa of Ibn Abbas.

narrators.name: Karib
narrators.alternative_names: Karib, the freed slave of Ibn Abbas

narrators.name: Ibn Abbas
narrators.full_name: Abdullah ibn Abbas ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Sharik ibn Abdullah is only 'Saduq Yahim' (reliable but with errors/confusion)
Husayn ibn Abdullah has unknown reliability status (majhul al-hal)
Ali explicitly rejected the hadith of the first chain's reporter
The text explicitly states this hadith 'did not become authentic' (wa-lam yasih)

potential_issues.impact: Sharik ibn Abdullah is only moderately reliable with documented errors, and Husayn ibn Abdullah has unknown reliability, weakening the chain
Ali explicitly stated 'I abandoned his hadith' regarding one of the reporters in the first chain, indicating known reliability problems
The text explicitly states regarding the version through Sharik 'wa-lam yasih' (it did not become authentic), indicating this version is not accepted even by the author

potential_issues.issue: Multiple variant chains with different assessments
potential_issues.impact: Different chains (through Karib, Sharik, and Amr) present different versions, with the text noting only Ibn Abbas's opinion is well-known, not a prophetic tradition

IISGrade: Weak But Might Be Acceptable
Topics: Incident of Umm Ibrahim and her status regarding manumission
Legal ruling on separation of mothers from children in slavery
Scholarly debate on the status of ummahat al-aulad (mother slaves)

english_translation: Narrated by Ahmad ibn Isa: Abdullah ibn Wahb narrated to us, Ibn Abi Dhi'b informed us, from Husayn ibn Abdullah ibn Dumayra, from his father, from his grandfather, that the Prophet ﷺ passed by Umm Dumayra while she was weeping, saying: 'My son is being separated from me.' He said: 'Do not separate a mother from her child,' then he sent to the one who had Dumayra, called him, and bought him (the child) from him with a young camel.

narrators.name: Abdullah ibn Wahb

narrators.name: Ibn Abi Dhi'b

chainIssues: Multiple narrators in the chain (Husayn ibn Abdullah, Abdullah ibn Dumayra, and the unnamed grandfather) have unknown reliability status (majhul al-hal or majhul)
These unknown narrators represent breaks or weak points in the chain despite the strength of Ahmad ibn Isa, Abdullah ibn Wahb, and Ibn Abi Dhi'b

potential_issues.impact: Husayn ibn Abdullah and his father Abdullah ibn Dumayra are both majhul al-hal, and Dumayra's grandfather is entirely unknown (majhul). These weak links significantly compromise the chain despite the strength of the first three narrators
The chain goes through multiple generations of the same family (Dumayra's grandfather → his father → his grandson) with no established reliability documentation for any of them

potential_issues.issue: Weak middle narrators despite strong beginning and end
potential_issues.impact: While Ahmad ibn Isa and Abdullah ibn Wahb are reliable, and Ibn Abi Dhi'b is trustworthy, the middle section through completely unknown Dumayra family members weakens the entire transmission

potential_issues.issue: Use of عَنْ with unknown narrators

IISGrade: Weak But Might Be Acceptable

Prophet's ﷺ prohibition of separating mothers from children
Incident of the Prophet ﷺ purchasing the freedom of a child

english_translation: Biographical account: Zayd ibn Habab said to me, Husayn ibn Waqid said: There was a trial (fitna) among us in Khorasan during the time of al-Karmani and Abi Muslim, I did not ask about it, nor did I ask until it passed. Ali ibn Husayn said: My father died in the year one hundred fifty-nine or one hundred fifty-seven.
